plusCode.compoundCode: Q27F+HJ Manhattan, New York, NY, USA

adrFormatAddress: 35 W 57th St, Manhattan, NY 10019, USA

originalText.text: This restaurant is a gem for Persian cuisine! We went for a bday celebration and the service, ambiance and food were divine! Iâ€™m still dreaming about the food and spices used. Nasrin was even in the back and greeted us! Highly recommend all the appetizers and you really canâ€™t go wrong with any of the main entrees. I was also pleasantly surprised that two of them could be made vegetarian and used mushrooms as the main staple. One of my favorite aspects was that the saffron rice platter would come with a little piece of tahdig on the side, there were all kinds of thoughtful details like that, that really garnished each dish and made the presentation. Stunning! Their deserts are also spectacular, the tea service was exquisite and came with a tray of sweets. We really felt like we were dining in someoneâ€™s lavish Persian home being fed, homemade authentic cuisine. Absolutely recommend if you are craving a feast with divine flavors!

originalText.text:
Discrete midtown walk up that opens the doors to a cozy Persian getaway. Very unique decor that took us on a culinary as well as cultural and musical journeyðŸ•Œ

Service was very authentic and nice. Ambience was incredible with Persian music. The food was so delicious and different from any middle eastern cuisine Iâ€™ve had here in nyc.

We ordered 3 apps, 4 drinks, 4 entrees, and a dessert and finished every single bite along the four of us. Not a single dish disappointed.

Would highly recommend coming here for both authentic food and great value.

originalText.text: My favorite items of the night were the fesenjoon and the chelo kebab koobideh. I usually donâ€™t like chicken but the fesenjoon was a beautiful mildly sweet chicken that fell off the bone, with pomegranate and a brown sauce. The bread was soft and warm, topped off with sesame seeds. The mast mosir was a yogurt dip that complemented the bread well, while also adding some crunch with cucumber bits (which I normally donâ€™t eat but thoroughly enjoyed). We also ordered the chicken kebab and two other stews. For dessert, we had the Persian tea which came with small dessert items, and the baklava which was very sweet. I came with my Persian friends who said the food was legit. The restaurant is a romantic dim candle-lit space that feels spacious. The music adds to the authenticity while the waiters were kind and attentive. This would make a great date night. Highly recommend making a reservation, as when we initially came as walk-ins they did not have availability. Bring cash for a discount.

originalText.text:
Straightforward traditional Iranian cuisine in a matching ambiance.
The menu is not crazy diverse and a bit maybe limited on the Kabobs but I personally didn't mind at all. The quality of food is decent, nothing overwhelming.
What stood out for me was that finally there is an Iranian restaurant in NYC where the music, waiters and overall ambiance are relatively Iranian and match the cuisine that you feel like you are eating home made food at Nasrin Joon's  Kitchen!

originalText.text: We had a very nice dinner here. The beef and Lamb kabobs were excellent along with the chicken. We had the eggplant appetizer and it was very good as well. Family run restaurant with a really friendly staff.
